channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Britain’s defense secretary said that Russian forces had failed to meet any of their goals in the first day of their invasion of Ukraine, citing the verified assessment of his country’s intelligence services. https://t.co/W7agOpQ8OP

European leaders agreed to a new set of sanctions on Russia, which they described as unprecedented for the EU in terms of size and reach. The measures will hit Russia’s access to technology and its elite’s abilities to travel and save money in Europe. https://t.co/UoS4ppcRxm

Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, was hit by missile strikes on Friday, the second day of Russia’s military offensive. Ukraine’s leaders told residents to “prepare Molotov cocktails” to defend the city.
Follow our updates on the Russian invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/8SpMVtutQe https://t.co/1DJdgusZpL

The Taliban called on Russia and Ukraine to resolve the crisis through “peaceful means.”
They asked both countries to safeguard Afghans in Ukraine. Ukrainian troops evacuated nearly 100 Afghans to Kyiv after the fall of Afghanistan’s government in August. https://t.co/Q89NxxkkJC

The U.S. met with China over three months to present intelligence showing Russia’s troop buildup near Ukraine and to urge Beijing to help avert war, U.S. officials said.
Chinese officials rebuffed the U.S. and shared the information with Moscow. https://t.co/Ngbuu9P3n1
UEFA, European soccer’s governing body, voted to move the Champions League final to Paris from St. Petersburg as punishment for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/TQpib57MBc

A large rocket landed in the middle of the street near the National Guard academy in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city. It was unclear if anyone was injured by the rocket, which failed to detonate.
Follow our updates on the Ukraine crisis. https://t.co/gzBSYhRUzy https://t.co/INGOkm8bBV

Kyiv was hit by missile strikes, with a rocket crashing into a residential building, as Russian forces pressed closer to the heart of the government.
Ukraine’s Defense Ministry urged people in the capital to stay indoors and “prepare Molotov cocktails.” https://t.co/cBrs6BNTeA https://t.co/rGqyJJXZD6

India's prime minister, Narendra Modi, said he appealed to President Vladimir Putin of Russia for a “cessation of violence,” but he fell short of condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/MkQ3W1XS5I

The UN Security Council on Friday plans to vote on a resolution condemning Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and calling for an immediate and unconditional withdrawal of its troops, according to a senior U.S. administration official. https://t.co/2QN0CYwQfF

Ukrainian border guards who died defending Snake Island when Russia attacked will all be posthumously titled "Hero of Ukraine."
In an audio clip, they used an expletive and refused to surrender the Black Sea island when ordered to by a Russian warship. https://t.co/jz1iNDDw7u

Breaking News: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine accused Russia of targeting civilian areas with rocket attacks. Ukrainian officials said there were multiple missile strikes in Kyiv, but the targets and damage remained unclear.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/CF209JqNuE

Ukraine's museums are scrambling to work out how to protect their collections. By the time they considered evacuating their most prized objects from Kyiv, the roads were already clogged with Ukrainians fleeing west. https://t.co/F1DRvFkhos

In Opinion
"It’s not our fight alone. So please don’t leave us alone to fight it," Veronika Melkozerova, a Ukrainian journalist in Kyiv, writes in a guest essay. https://t.co/LZIX3r71Nw

Ex-heads of government left the boards of some prominent Russian companies on Thursday in protest over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, except one of the most prominent — Germany’s ex-chancellor, Gerhard Schröder. https://t.co/q40bKiNa5O
Breaking News: The CDC is expected to loosen guidelines for when and where Americans should wear masks, allowing most people to go without them indoors. https://t.co/yQSw6ZwEoQ
U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin ordered an additional 7,000 troops to Europe with the continent facing the biggest land war since World War II. https://t.co/eTDX79Xqwf

"Stand with Ukraine!" some protesters chanted. "Sanctions now!" said others.
Demonstrators have taken to the streets in cities across the world to condemn Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and express solidarity with the Ukrainian people. https://t.co/uHbSrQ8ieu https://t.co/3uWqHvTPF2
GOP leaders, while condemning Russia, were silent on Donald Trump’s comments praising Vladimir Putin. Some on the right amplified them. https://t.co/UCyz1iAX9L

News Analysis: President Vladimir Putin’s speech seemed close to threatening nuclear war than any statement from a world leader in decades, Roger Cohen writes. But his purpose was clear: to make clear he would not hesitate to escalate. https://t.co/4lvn2u4T7K

Some people waited in lines at bus stations or sat in huge traffic jams, hoping for a way out. Some put up a defiant face and vowed to fight Russian intruders.
Photographers around Ukraine captured moments of uncertainty and fear as Russia invaded. https://t.co/QeDg6fBFEn https://t.co/aDYWM3daiO

Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said that he remained in the country despite rumors that he had fled. “The enemy has marked me as target No. 1,” he said, “my family as target No. 2.” https://t.co/GVzgFZl5Fj https://t.co/2aUvSZwILn

Ukrainians living in the U.S. are watching in horror as Russia attacks their homeland.
"Americans have to realize that this is about freedom and being able to live one’s life as they see fit," one man said. https://t.co/vWCt3xnspI

Videos showed a large explosion in the sky and debris falling over parts of Kyiv, Ukraine, early on Friday. The videos, verified by The New York Times, appeared to show at least two surface to air missiles being fired from Kyiv.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/tJZkqhauZ5

A chorus of Russian celebrities and public figures have condemned President Vladimir Putin’s decision to invade Ukraine. Ksenia Sobchak, a TV celebrity, said she would only "believe in the worst possible scenarios” about her country’s future from now on. https://t.co/HIyTiTgZQt https://t.co/CgKVpvocpi

Newborn infants from the neonatal intensive care unit at a children’s hospital in Dnipro, in eastern Ukraine, were moved into a makeshift bomb shelter on a lower level of the building on Thursday. https://t.co/l8RAcFMTud https://t.co/kWud9ktt2P

With flags and signs with slogans in both Ukrainian and English, hundreds of Ukrainians and other New Yorkers marched through Manhattan Thursday to protest Russia's invasion of Ukraine and condemn President Vladimir Putin. https://t.co/XYKBh1lmGt

Some refugee resettlement leaders in the U.S. called on the Biden administration to prepare to welcome people fleeing Ukraine for their lives as fears grow that the Russian invasion could trigger a major exodus. https://t.co/AL3B0AN6Gn https://t.co/2N9BDBYxIJ

Newborn infants from the neonatal intensive care unit at a children’s hospital in Dnipro, Ukraine, were moved into a makeshift bomb shelter on a lower level of the building.
“This is the NICU. In a bomb shelter. Can you imagine?” Dr. Denis Surkov said. https://t.co/EYvv64bVbZ

President Biden said the U.S. would cut off Russia’s largest banks and companies from the Western financial markets and restrict exports of technology to Russia. “Putin chose this war, and now he and his country will bear the consequences,” Biden said. https://t.co/sZoUyfYjQX https://t.co/mcvpH2VSX7

As Russia continues its assault, videos give some insight into how Ukraine’s military is trying to mount a defense. In this video, filmed about 12 miles south of Kyiv, the capital, a pilot parachutes into the Dnieper River as smoke rises from it. https://t.co/34iy2oTinp https://t.co/s5zyVtQOg1

Brazil issued a tepid response to Russia’s attacks on Ukraine, calling for a peaceful solution that “takes into account the legitimate security interests of all parties involved.” The statement came a week after President Bolsonaro visited President Putin. https://t.co/zxwaBzrmog

The U.S. and Europe responded to Russia's invasion of Ukraine with economic sanctions. Do sanctions really work? @SangerNYT in Washington and @PatcohenNYT in London discuss the outlook on Friday, Feb. 25, at 2 p.m. ET. DM questions to @nytimesevents. https://t.co/oDYeOWwchB

Ukraine’s president said in a video address that Russian saboteurs had entered Kyiv, and that he was “target No. 1” for Moscow.
Follow our live updates. https://t.co/tLDS7IrU2g

Valery Gergiev, a friend and supporter of President Vladimir Putin, will no longer lead a series of concerts at Carnegie Hall this week after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the venue and Vienna Philharmonic announced on Thursday. https://t.co/nk1wOjZhIw

"We are defending our home." Ukraine’s ambassador to Washington on Thursday said her country does "not expect anyone to fight for us," adding that at least 40 Ukrainian troops have already been killed by Russia, along with "dozens" of Ukrainian civilians. https://t.co/0S9wES6As2

Ukraine’s ambassador to the U.S., Oksana Markarova, said that hospitals and the sealed Chernobyl nuclear disaster site were among the areas hit by Russian forces. “We will defend our country, and we are not scared,” she said. https://t.co/ATx9UogKws https://t.co/tVGY2Cioho

Prime Minister Boris Johnson said Britain would impose more sanctions against Russian banks, companies and oligarchs; restrict technology exports into Russia; and ban Russia's airline in retaliation for the invasion of Ukraine.
Follow the latest. https://t.co/cySpWsmzy1 https://t.co/qelVizajWk

Breaking News: A jury found three former Minneapolis police officers guilty of violating George Floyd’s civil rights during the arrest that killed him, by failing to intervene when Derek Chauvin pressed his knee on Floyd's neck for over nine minutes. https://t.co/SzLJEdWZYK

The Russian invasion of Ukraine is threatening to cut off some international shipments of wheat. Russia and Ukraine together produce nearly a quarter of the world’s wheat, feeding billions of people. https://t.co/w3fk9HzdJy

Here's what the first day of Russia's invasion of Ukraine looked like around the country. The attack left dozens dead and drew new sanctions that President Biden said would buckle Russia’s economy. Follow live updates as the fighting continues. https://t.co/dQyc5v1EbW https://t.co/e7Men35AJa

The Pentagon is sending an additional 7,000 troops to Europe, the Pentagon said on Thursday. The defense secretary ordered the deployment of an armored brigade combat team to Germany to reassure NATO allies, the Pentagon said in a statement. https://t.co/BDQCoyFsWn

About 2,500 people gathered at the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin on Thursday to protest against the Russian invasion. For the second time this week, the city had illuminated the landmark in blue and yellow to express solidarity with Ukraine.
Follow updates: https://t.co/hKLhojLcq4 https://t.co/XH3ax96Q36

Oxxxymiron, one of Russia’s most popular rappers, called for an antiwar movement to be created in Russia. “This is a crime and a catastrophe,” he said, adding that he will cancel his six sold-out concerts in Moscow and St. Petersburg. https://t.co/rWErwXnT7f https://t.co/rSH9fAKfLs
Russia's invasion will upend the lives of 44 million Ukrainians. But effects of the attack on Ukraine, on the edge of Europe, will extend far beyond its borders. https://t.co/sffJnW9gRd

Ukraine’s ambassador to Washington on Thursday said her country does "not expect anyone to fight for us," adding that at least 40 Ukrainian troops have already been killed by Russia, along with "dozens" of Ukrainian civilians. https://t.co/jRsjrHmLI0 https://t.co/5p9y6nFPex

Ukrainians living across Europe watched in horror as Russia’s invasion of their home country began. "The whole world knows about it, and no one is doing anything," said Inna Tereshchuk, who has family members in Ukraine. https://t.co/IetYXDwdQq

Breaking News: In his first public remarks since Russia's assault on Ukraine began, President Biden emphasized again that American troops were “not going to Europe to fight in Ukraine,” but said that every inch of NATO territory would be defended. https://t.co/U5BlJ15gy1 https://t.co/oJlHGNthus

More than 40 Ukrainian soldiers have been killed and dozens wounded after Russia attacked airports and military installations in Ukraine, according to Ukrainian officials. https://t.co/hBZ9mlihnm https://t.co/hqjnyve691

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, a former television actor and comic, has become a wartime leader, a role few expected for him. Ukrainians have rallied around him as he faces the greatest crisis in his country’s modern history. https://t.co/cdZNcfCPpv
